timeline.message:
[ML] Perform test inference in java

Since we are able to load the inference model
and perform inference in java, we no longer need
to rely on the analytics process to be performing
test inference on the docs that were not used for
training. The benefit is that we do not need to
send test docs and fit them in memory of the c++
process.
Stop sending test data to c++
Add test for cancelling inference runner
Add tests for progress with or without inference

timeline.bodyText: Why is this set to true for RegressionEvaluationIT but false for ClassificationEvaluationIT?
timeline.author: przemekwitek

timeline.bodyText: nit: this is a very generic message can we be more precise. Is this testing?
timeline.author: davidkyle

replies.bodyText: I have reworded this one and removed the "finished" one.
replies.author: dimitris-athanasiou

timeline.bodyText: I'm pleased you've implemented the progress meter gets to fixed number then stalls for ages feature
timeline.author: davidkyle

replies.bodyText:
Hehe! It's not what it looks like!
@przemekwitek This answer should also cover your question about the magic 98.
So, this is a fairly linear progress here. We go through the test docs, infer, and bulk index when we have a batch. The only reason we want to hold the progress from going 100, is that after we infer the last doc there's still a bulk index action pending and we don't want to appear completed before that.
Why 98 instead of 99, just to make room for a slow bulk index. :-)
replies.author: dimitris-athanasiou

timeline.bodyText:
Looks like a partial refactoring, a public method should not be called internalX.
This does not update the stats fields as infer() does is that intentional?
timeline.author: davidkyle

replies.bodyText: I agree. I'll rename this to inferNoStats. Indeed, we intentionally don't want to account stats here as it's not an explicit user action but rather the implicit consequence of running the job that trains the model in the first place.
replies.author: dimitris-athanasiou

timeline.bodyText: Whats the behaviour here if the documents in the index change between batches e.g. if more are added or removed? Will the value getTotalHits() change?
timeline.author: davidkyle

replies.bodyText:
Good point. I only track total hits in the first search to avoid possible overhead after the first time. But in an index that is receiving new docs that number may become outdated. Not sure what's the best way to go about this though. I could make an extra search request just for getting the total hits count instead of adding this here. But I'm not sure.
An alternative design would be for the SearchAfterDocumentsIterator to allow for a sub-class to add this and then take care of it only in the TestDocsIterator where we know we're dealing with a static index.
Open to ideas.
replies.author: dimitris-athanasiou

replies.bodyText:
You could used BatchedDocumentsIterator which uses scroll but testing may take a while and you have to keep the context alive.
Do you expect any changes to the underlying index when this is running? TBH this is only used in the progress meter which are notoriously imprecise. Embrace the imprecision and let that progress meter bounce up and down
replies.author: davidkyle

replies.bodyText: I ended up adding a comment that explains how total hits are tracked.
replies.author: dimitris-athanasiou

timeline.message: Add comment for trackick total hits
